revision.text:
[[File:Brooklyn Museum 35.679 Elephant Tusk Carved with Figures in Relief.jpg|thumbnail|Kongo Elephant Tusk Carved with Figures in Relief, from the collections of the Brooklyn Museum]] '''Kongo ivories''' are some of the finest sculptural works produced by the people of the west-central Africa's Lower Congo region. In the [[Kongo Kingdom]], [[ivory]] was a precious commodity that was strictly controlled by chiefs and kings, who commissioned sculptors to produce fine ivory sculptures for their personal and courtly use. With the rise of the [[Atlantic slave trade|transatlantic trade]], ivory became one of the most valuable African [[natural resources]] sought by Western industry. Eventually, Kongo ivory carvers produced works not only for indigenous leaders and elites but also for Europeans and other foreigners.<ref name="Met Museum">{{cite web|last=Bridges|first=Nichole N.|title=Kongo Ivories|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/kong/hd_kong.htm|work=Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref>
==Afro-Portuguese ivories== Most of the earliest extant ivory carvings from sub-Saharan Africa were not made for African consumers.<ref name="Ross 1992">{{cite book|last=Ross|first=Doran|title=Elephant : the animal and its ivory in African culture|year=1992|publisher=Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California|location=Los Angeles|isbn=0930741250|authorlink=Imagining Elephants: An Overview|editor=Doran Ross}}</ref> Richly decorated oliphants, or side-blown horns, from the sixteenth century are among the earliest known of the Kongo Kingdom's royal commissions in ivory. Although made in the form of musical instruments to be used during court ceremonies, many such sculptures were likely given as gifts and made for sale to Portuguese elites, missionaries, and traders.<ref name="Met Museum" /> In the 1950s, historian [[William Buller Fagg|William Fagg]] coined the term “Afro-Portuguese ivories” to describe Kongo oliphants and other ivory sculptures from this period.<ref name="Fagg 1958">{{cite book|last=Fagg|first=William|title=Afro-Portuguese Ivories|year=1958|publisher=Batchworth Press|location=London}}</ref><ref>Emma George Ross, [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/apiv/hd_apiv.htm "Afro-Portuguese Ivories"] ''Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History''. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, October 2002.</ref> A significant number of Afro-Portuguese ivories are in the [[British Museum]], many of them made in [[Sierra Leone]] and Benin in the 15th and 16th centuries.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=Carved+ivory+Sierra+Leone British Museum Collection]</ref><ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=Carved+salt-cellar+Benin British Museum Collection]</ref>
==Carved ivories for export== About the middle of the nineteenth century, a new style of ivory carving developed in the area to meet the demand of the export trade along the [[Loango Kingdom|Loango Coast]] of west-central Africa. This style consisted of fine, detailed relief carving that depicts scenes of Kongo life.<ref name=Siegmann>{{cite book|last=Siegmann|first=William C.|title=African art a century at the Brooklyn Museum|year=2009|publisher=Brooklyn Museum|location=Brooklyn, NY|isbn=9780872731639}}</ref> Scenes commonly portrayed in relief on the ivories capture the dynamic and cosmopolitan coastal activity related to the transatlantic trade.
Most carved Loango tusks are not longer than two to three feet because they were sourced from forest elephants, which are much smaller than the African savannah elephant. Full Loango tusk sculptures that were sculpted from the enormous tusks of savannah elephants are extremely rare; one notable example is now part of the [[Brooklyn Museum]]’s collection.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/71017/rec/1 For spirits and kings: African art from the Paul and Ruth Tishman collection], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on Kongo ivories
[[Category:African art]] [[Category:Ivory works of art]]

{{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Lily Sobhani | image = | imagesize= 225px | caption = Lily Sobhani, 2007, with Al Gore. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1976|10|15}} | birth_place = [[Norfolk, England]] | occupation = Worldwide Events Producer, Producer }} '''Lily Sobhani''', born 15 October 1976 in [[Norfolk, England]], is a live events producer who specializes in producing large, internationally broadcast music events, usually with a charity component.
==Life== Lily Sobhani has been working in music and live event production for 15 years, and in that time she has produced, promoted, distributed and messaged countless cause-related and charity concerts. Her first major production as an executive producer was the original [[Make Trade Fair#Make_Trade_Fair_concerts|Fairplay]] concert in 2002 for Oxfam’s [[Make Trade Fair]] campaign, which she produced through her company Bottle,<ref>[http://www.cwu.org/one-big-no-musicians-and-artists-against-the-war..html?archive_page=114 "ONE BIG NO - musicians and artists against the war", The Communications Union, 6 March 2003] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717042926/http://www.cwu.org/one-big-no-musicians-and-artists-against-the-war..html?archive_page=114 |date=17 July 2011 }}</ref> with partners [[Emily Eavis]] and [[Marianne Troup]].
==Career== ===Live 8=== In June 2005, Sobhani was called upon by the Make Poverty History coalition to execute a concert in Japan for the [[Live 8]] concert series. In a span of 4 weeks, Sobhani accomplished the impossible task of securing the venue, artists, broadcast partners and financing, and developing local messaging, for the event at [[Makuhari Messe]] in Japan, on the outskirts of Tokyo. The show, [[Live 8 concert, Chiba]], prompted the Japanese Government to add 2 billion dollars more aid for the poorest countries of the world a few days later.<ref>[http://www.whiteband.org/media/gcap-news/archives/gcapnews.2007-04-19.7685898026/ "Japan’s Live 8 Concert!", GCAP Asia, 4 July 2005] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110054303/http://www.whiteband.org/media/gcap-news/archives/gcapnews.2007-04-19.7685898026 |date=10 January 2008 }}</ref>
===Live Earth=== During that experience Sobhani met [[Kevin Wall]], founder of [[Live Earth]] and Exec Producer of Live 8, and when Live Earth was conceived, she was one of the first people he called on. Lily became Worldwide Head of Events,<ref>[http://liveearth.org/sv/press/pressrelease/live-earth-australia-revealed "Live Earth Australia Revealed" Live Earth, 7 May 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001123716/http://liveearth.org/sv/press/pressrelease/live-earth-australia-revealed |date= 1 October 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://bellsouthpwp.net/t/p/tplipps/scaryguy/245500-2.htm "Live Earth Credits"]</ref> responsible for the delivery of all Live Earth music concerts. In this capacity, Sobhani supervised teams responsible for all facets of production – from staging and lighting design to promotion, finance, broadcast capture and distribution and artist coordination. The original [[Live Earth (2007 concert)|Live Earth]] was a set of 9 concerts staged on 7 continents over 24 hours, and was broadcast to 2 billion people on 7 July 2007. It became the largest global entertainment event ever held.
Following this, Sobhani was again tapped by Kevin Wall to produce an additional Live Earth concert to take place in [[Mumbai, India]]. [[Live Earth#Live Earth India 2008|Live Earth India]] was scheduled to take place 7 December 2008. Unfortunately, the concert was cancelled shortly after the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks]] on 26 November 2008.
In early 2010, Sobhani was asked last minute to step in and help oversee the Chicago portion of the [[Live Earth#Dow_Live_Earth_Run_for_Water|Live Earth Run for Water]].
===FIFA World Cup Kick-Off Celebration Concert===
Most recently, Lily Sobhani produced the inaugural Official FIFA 2010 World Cup Kickoff Celebration Concert,<ref>[http://www.access-aa.co.uk/news/2009/10/concert-to-kick-off-2010-world-cup.aspx "Concert to kick off 2010 World Cup", Access All Areas]</ref><ref>[http://www.artlink.co.za/news_article.htm?contentID=8675 "First-ever FIFA kick-off celebration concert" Artslink.co.za, 7 October 2009]</ref> which opened the 2010 FIFA World Cup tournament on 10 June. It featured live performances from Black Eyed Peas, Shakira, Alicia Keys, John Legend and Juanes, as well as an amazing blend of African artists including Amadou & Mariam, Angelique Kidjo, BLK JKS and Tinariwen.
=== The Secret Policeman's Ball===
Most recently, Lily Sobhani executive produced the American reboot of [[The Secret Policeman's Ball 2012|The Secret Policeman's Ball]] at the Radio City Music Hall in New York on March 4, 2012, a celebration of Amnesty International's 50th Anniversary. The event was a tremendous success with a focus on comedy: [[Russell Brand]], [[Jon Stewart]], [[Rashida Jones]], [[Chris O'Dowd]], [[Jason Sudeikis]], [[Paul Rudd]], [[Catherine Tate]], [[Noel Fielding]], [[Jimmy Carr]], [[Sarah Silverman]], [[David Cross]], [[Ben Stiller]], [[David Walliams]], [[Liam Neeson]], [[Jack Whitehall]] and many more all taking to the stage. Together with these comedy stars, [[Coldplay]] and [[Mumford & Sons]] played sets, headlining the event.
Lily currently resides in Los Angeles, CA.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sobhani, Lily}} [[Category:British theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Women theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1976 births]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/24.157.72.47|24.157.72.47]] ([[User talk:24.157.72.47|talk]]) to last version by Freshacconci
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=February 2018}} '''Art media''' is the [[material]] used by an [[artist]], [[composer]] or [[designer]] to [[Creativity|create]] a [[work of art]]. This is a list of types of art and the materials used within those types.{{TOC right}}
==Architecture== {{main|Outline of architecture|Building material}} *[[cement]], [[concrete]], [[Mortar (masonry)|mortar]] *[[Cob (material)|cob]] *[[Glass#Architecture|glass]] *[[metal]] *[[Rock (geology)|stone]], [[brick]] *[[wood]]
==Carpentry== {{Further information|List of woods}} *[[adhesives]] *[[wood]] ([[timber]])
==Ceramics== {{Main article|Ceramic art}} *[[bone china]] *[[clay]] *[[Ceramic glaze|glaze]] *[[porcelain]] *[[pottery]] *[[terracotta]]
==Drawing== {{main|Outline of drawing and drawings}} ===Traditional drawing media===
*[[acrylic paint]] *[[airbrush]] *[[chalk]] *[[Charcoal (art)|charcoal]] *[[conté]] *[[crayon]] *[[oil pastel]] *[[soft pastel]] *[[gouache]] *[[graphite]] *[[Finger|human finger]] *[[oil paint]] *[[pastel]] *[[Pen|pen and ink]] **[[ballpoint pen]] **[[fountain pen]] **[[gel pen]] **[[technical pen]] **[[Marker pen|marker]] *[[pencil]] **[[coloured pencil]] *[[sand]] *[[tempera]] *[[watercolor]]
=== Indigenous materials for painting === *[[Elito Circa|human hair and blood]] *various [[Body fluid#Body fluids in art|bodily fluids and excrement]] including [[Chris Ofili|elephant dung]] *[[solar energy]] *[[garlic]] *[[rust]] *[[coffee]] *[[onion]] *[[coconut juice]] *[[mud]] *[[black palm]] *[[tomato]] *[[soy sauce]] *[[Staple (fastener)|staple wire]]
=== Common bases for drawing === *[[canvas]] *[[card stock]] *[[fabric]] *[[glass]] *[[human body]] *[[metal]] *[[paper]] *[[plaster]] *[[scratchboard]] *[[vellum]] *[[Wall|walls]] *[[wood]]
==Electronic== {{main|Electronic art||Digital art|Electronic media}} *[[graphic art software]] and [[3D computer graphics]] *[[word processor]]s and [[desktop publishing]] software *[[digital photography]] and [[digital cinematography]] *specialized input devices (e.g. [[graphics tablet|variable pressure sensing tablet]]s and [[touchscreen]]s) *[[digital printing]] *[[Programming language|programming languages]]
==Film== {{main|Outline of film|Cinematic techniques}} *[[animation]] *[[computer animation]] and [[computer-generated imagery]] <!-- the following MAY be methods or genres, but ARE NOT media: *[[experimental film]] *[[live action]] *[[Films with live action and animation|Live action and animation]] *[[Stop motion]] *[[Structural film]] --> *[[Video art]] and its subsets [[single-channel video]] and [[video installation]]
==Food== {{main|Culinary art}} A chef's tools and equipment, including ovens, stoves, grills, and griddles. Specialty equipment may be used, including [[Grilling#Salamander|salamanders]], [[French top]]s, woks, [[tandoor]]s, and [[induction burner]]s.
== Glass == [[Glassblowing]], [[Glass coloring and color marking|colouring and marking]] methods
== Installation == {{Main|Installation art}} [[Installation art]] is a site-specific form of [[sculpture]] that can be created with any material. An installation can occupy a large amount of [[space]], create an [[wikt:ambiance|ambience]], transform/disrupt the space, exist in the space. One way to distinguish an installation from a sculpture (this may not apply to every installation) is to try to imagine it in a different space. If the objects present difficulties in a different space than the original, it is probably an installation.
==Light== {{further|Lighting designer}}
==Literature== {{main|Literature|Writing implement}}
===Traditional writing media=== *[[Electronic literature|digital]] [[word processor]] *[[internet]] [[website]]s *[[letterpress printing]] *[[Printer (computing)|computer printers]] *[[Marker pen|marker]] *[[Pen|pen and ink]] or *[[quill]] *[[pencil]]
=== Common bases for writing === *[[card stock]] *[[paper]], perhaps [[Ruled paper|ruled]] *[[vellum]]
==Natural world== {{main|Gardening|Landscape architecture}} *[[floral design]] *[[Rock (geology)|rock]] *[[soil]] *[[vegetation]] *[[water]]
==Painting== {{main|Outline of painting}} ===Traditional paint media=== *[[Acrylic paint]] *[[Blacklight paint]] *[[Encaustic painting|Encaustic paint]] *[[Fresco]] *[[Gesso]] *[[Glaze (painting technique)|Glaze]] *[[Gouache]] *[[Ink]] *[[Latex]] paint *[[Magna paint]] *[[Oil paint]] *[[Primer (paint)|Primer]] *[[Stencil]] *[[Ink wash painting|Ink wash]] (sumi-e) *[[Tempera]] or [[poster paint]] *[[Vinyl group|Vinyl]] paint (toxic/poisonous) *[[Vitreous enamel]] *[[Watercolor]]
===Supports for painting=== *[[Architectural structure]]s *[[Canvas]] *[[Ceramic]]s *[[Cloth]] *[[Glass]] *[[Human body]] (typically for [[tattoos]]) *[[Metal]] *[[Paper]] *[[Paperboard]] *[[Vellum]] *[[Wall]] *[[Wood]]
===Traditional tools and methods=== *[[Action painting]] *[[Aerosol paint]] *[[Airbrush]] *[[Batik]] *[[Brush#Paintbrushes|Brush]] *[[Textile|Cloth]] *[[Paint roller]] or [[paint pad]] *[[Palette knife]] *[[Sponge (material)|Sponge]]
===Mural techniques=== [[Mural]]ists use many of the same media as [[Panel painting|panel painters]], but due to the scale of their works, use different techniques. Some such techniques include: *[[Aerosol paint]] *[[Digital painting]] *[[Fresco]] *[[Image projector]] *[[Mosaic]] *[[Pounce (art)|Pounce art]]
===Graphic narrative media=== {{main|Graphic narrative}} [[Comics creators]] use many of the same media as traditional painters.
==Performing arts== {{Main|Performing arts|Performance art}} The [[performing arts]] is a form of [[entertainment]] that is created by the artist's own [[Human body|body]], [[face]] and presence as a medium. There are many skills and [[Performance#Performance genres|genres]] of [[performance]], [[dance]], [[theatre]] and [[Historical reenactment|re-enactment]] being examples. [[Performance art]] is a performance that may not present a conventional formal linear [[narrative]].
==Photography== {{main|Outline of photography}} In [[photography]] a [[photosensitive]] surface is used to capture an optical still image, usually utilizing a [[Lens (optics)|lens]] to focus [[light]]. Some media include: *Digital [[image sensor]] *[[Photographic film]] *[[Potassium dichromate]] *[[Potassium ferricyanide]] and [[ferric ammonium citrate]] *[[Silver nitrate]]
==Printmaking== In the art of [[printmaking]], "media" tends to refer to the technique used to create a print. Common media include: *[[Aquatint]] *[[Printer (computing)|Computer printing]] **[[Dye-sublimation printer]] **[[Inkjet printer]] (sometimes called [[giclée]] printing) **[[Laser printer]] **[[Solid ink|Solid ink printer]] **[[Thermal printer]] *[[Embossing (paper)|Embossing]] *[[Engraving]] *[[Etching]] *[[Intaglio (printmaking)]] *[[Letterpress printing|Letterpress]] (literature) *[[Linocut]] *[[Lithography]] *[[Mezzotint]] *[[Moku hanga]] *[[Monotype]] *[[Offset printing]] *[[Photographic printing]] *[[Planographic printing]] *[[Printing press]] *[[Relief print]]ing **[[Linocut]] **[[Metalcut]] **[[Etching#Variants: aquatint, soft-ground and relief etching|Relief etching]] **[[Wood engraving]] **[[Woodcut]] *[[Screen-printing]] *[[Woodblock printing]]
==Sculpture== {{main|Outline of sculpture}} In [[sculpture|sculpting]], a [[solid]] [[structure]] and [[wikt:texture|textured]] surface is shaped or combined using [[Physical property|substance]]s and components, to form a three-dimensional object. The size of a sculptured work can be built very big and could be considered as [[architecture]], although more commonly a large [[statue]] or [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]], and can be crafted very small and intricate as [[jewellery]], [[Ornament (art)|ornament]]s and decorative [[relief]]s.
===Materials===
====Carving media==== *[[Bone carving]] *[[Bronze]] *[[Gemstone]]s *[[Glass]] *[[Granite]] *[[Ice]] *[[Ivory]] *[[Marble]] *[[Plaster]] *[[Stone]] *[[Wax]] *[[Wood]]
====Casting media==== *[[Cement]] *[[Ceramic]]s *[[Metal]] *[[Plaster]] *[[Plastic]] *[[Synthetic resin]] *[[Wax]]
====Modeling media==== *[[Clay]] *[[Papier-mâché]] *[[Plaster]] *[[Sand]] *[[Styrofoam]]
====Assembled media==== *[[Bead]]s *[[Corrugated fiberboard]] (cardboard) *[[Eating|Edible]] material *[[Foil (metal)|Foil]] *[[Found object]]s *[[Glue]] and other [[adhesive]]s *[[Paperboard]] *[[Textile]] *[[Wire]] *[[Wood]]
====Finishing materials==== *[[Acid]]s to create a [[patina]] ([[Corrosive substance|corrosive]]) *[[Glaze (painting technique)|Glaze]] *[[Polychrome]] *[[Wax]]
===Tools=== *[[Bristle]] [[brush]] *[[Chisel]] and [[hammer]] (modern [[pneumatic]]) *[[Clamp (tool)|Clamp]] or [[vise]] *[[Hammer]] or [[mallet]] (modern pneumatic) *[[Kiln]] for heating [[ceramic]]s and [[metal]]s *[[Knife]] *[[Pliers]] *[[Potter's wheel]] *[[Power tools]] *[[Sandpaper]] *[[Saw]] *[[Hand scraper|Scraper]] *[[Tin snips|Snips]] *[[Welding]] and [[Oxy-fuel welding and cutting|cutting torch]] *[[Wirecutter]]
==Sound== {{main|List of musical instruments|Music theory}} The art of [[sound]] can be singular or a combination of [[speech]] or objects and crafted [[Musical instrument|instrument]]s, to create sounds, [[rhythm]]s and [[music]] for a range of sonic [[Hearing (sense)|hearing]] purposes. See also [[music]] and [[sound art]].
==Technical products== {{further|Industrial design|Product design|Engineering}} The use of [[technology|technical]] products as an art medium is a merging of [[applied art]] and [[applied science|science]], that may involve [[aesthetics]], [[efficiency]] and [[ergonomics]] using various materials.
==Textiles== In the art of [[textile]]s a soft and flexible material of [[fiber]]s or [[yarn]] is formed by spinning [[wool]], [[flax]], [[cotton]], or other material on a [[spinning wheel]] and [[crochet]]ing, [[knitting]], [[macramé]] ([[knot]]ting), [[weaving]], or pressing fibres together ([[felt]]) to create a work.
==See also== {{Portal|Arts}} * [[Collage]] * [[Conceptual art]] * [[Decorative arts]] * [[Design tool]] * [[Fashion design]] * [[Fine art]] * [[Fire performance]] * [[Fresco]] * [[Graffiti]] * [[Graphic arts]] * [[Liberal arts]] * [[List of pen types, brands and companies]] * [[Mixed media]] * [[Multimedia]] * [[New materials in 20th-century art]] * [[Plastic arts]] * [[Publishing]] * [[Pyrotechnics]] * [[Data storage device#Recording medium|Recording medium]] * [[Stationery]] * [[Video game art]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.getty.edu/vow/AATFullDisplay?find=media&logic=AND&note=&english=N&prev_page=1&subjectid=300163343 Media (artists' materials)] — ''definition from the Getty Art & Architecture Thesaurus''. *[http://www.iep.utm.edu/art-medi/ Artistic Medium], ''Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy''
{{Wiktionary|media|medium}} {{commonscat-multi|Art by material|Art by medium}}
{{Branches of the visual arts}} {{art world}}{{Decorative arts}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Artistic Media}} [[Category:Art media|*01]] [[Category:Art materials|*Media]] [[Category:Arts-related lists|*Media]] [[Category:Ceramic materials]] [[Category:Painting materials]] [[Category:Sculpture materials]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Mávila Huertas | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Mávila Milagros Huertas Centurión | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|12|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Arequipa]], Peru | death_place = | death_date = | height = 1.62 m | children = | spouse = Roberto Reátegui (2009–2013) | occupation = Journalist, writer, actress, radio and television presenter | alma_mater = [[University of Lima]] | years_active = 1992 – present }}
'''Mávila Milagros Huertas Centurión''' (born 24 December 1970) is a [[Peru]]vian journalist, writer, actress, and radio and television presenter.
==Biography== The daughter of José Huertas and Amarilis Centurión, Mávila studied [[Communication studies|communication sciences]] at the [[University of Lima]]. She later contributed to the magazine ''Somos'' and was the main editor of the magazine ''Intercambio''.
In 1992, Huertas began to work as an [[Investigative journalism|investigative reporter]] for several television channels. She put together the journalistic team of ''Contrapunto'' on [[Latina Televisión]] and later worked under the direction of {{ill|César Hildebrandt|es}} on the program ''La Clave''. She was in charge of producing reports for ''{{ill|América Noticias (Peru)|es|América noticias (Perú)|lt=América Noticias}}'' and ''Primera Edición'' on [[América Televisión]].
On [[Panamericana Televisión]], Huertas hosted the programs ''{{ill|Buenos Días, Perú|es}}'' and ''Reportajes'', as well as presenting the news show ''{{ill|ATV Noticias|es}}'' on [[Andina de Televisión|ATV]].
For several years she taught journalism at the [[Universidad Peruana de Ciencias Aplicadas]].
In 2001 she won the third National Journalism Competition in the category of Best Television Report for "Milagro en Sonene", about [[Yellow-spotted river turtle|Taricaya turtle]] conservation efforts in native communities in the Peruvian jungle.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.terra.com.pe/noticias/publi/publi020710.shtml |title=Telefónica del Perú convoca III Concurso Nacional de Periodismo |trans-title=Telefónica of Peru Announces the Third National Journalism Competition |website=Terra |language=Spanish |date=10 July 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004041311/http://www.terra.com.pe/noticias/publi/publi020710.shtml |archive-date=4 October 2015 |dead-url=yes |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In 2003 she participated as an actress in the Argentine feature film ''{{ill|Ojos que no ven|es}}'', alongside {{ill|Patricia Pereyra (actress)|es|Patricia Pereyra (actriz)|lt=Patricia Pereyra}}, [[Carlos Alcántara Vilar|Carlos Alcántara]], {{ill|Gustavo Bueno (actor)|es|lt=Gustavo Bueno}}, and {{ill|Gianfranco Brero|es}}. She also acted in the short film ''Desaparecida''.
Later she headed the central edition of the news program ''{{ill|América Noticias (Peru)|es|América noticias (Perú)|lt=América Noticias}}'' on América Televisión.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://larepublica.pe/07-08-2012/mavila-huertas-el-dia-que-veten-una-noticia-me-voy |title=Mávila Huertas: 'El día que veten una noticia, me voy' |trans-title=Mávila Huertas: 'The day they veto a story, I'm leaving' |last=Arana |first=Renato |work=[[La República]] |language=Spanish |date=7 August 2012 |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref> As an announcer, she briefly hosted the news show ''Hoy por Hoy'' on [[CPN Radio]].
In 2009, she published the book ''Los Reyes del Mambo: diez historias para entender el éxito en el Perú'' (The Kings of Mambo: Ten Stories to Understand Success in Peru).<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YpqhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT163 |title=Multinationals in Latin America: Case Studies |editor1-last=Liberman |editor1-first=Leonardo |editor2-last=Garcilazo |editor2-first=Sergio |editor3-last=Stal |editor3-first=Eva |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] |page=163 |isbn=9781137024114 |date=2 December 2014 |access-date=1 August 2017 |via=Google Books}}</ref>
Huertas married producer Roberto Reátegui in December 2009.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://peru21.pe/noticia/386302/mavila-huerta-paso-fila-casadas |title=Mávila Huertas pasó a la fila de las casadas |trans-title=Mávila Huertas Joins the Ranks of the Married |last=Mendoza |first=Karina |work=[[Perú.21]] |language=Spanish |date=26 December 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307031002/http://peru21.pe/noticia/386302/mavila-huerta-paso-fila-casadas |archive-date=7 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref> They divorced in May 2013.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://larepublica.pe/02-05-2013/mavila-huertas-anuncio-que-se-divorcia-de-roberto-reategui |title=Mávila Huertas anunció que se divorcia de Roberto Reátegui |trans-title=Mávila Huertas Announced That She is Divorced From Roberto Reátegui |work=[[La República]] |language=Spanish |date=2 May 2013 |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In 2011 she wrote and directed the documentary ''Machu Picchu, la joya del emperador'' (Machu Picchu, The Jewel of the Emperor).<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://archivo.elcomercio.pe/tvmas/television/manana-se-estrena-documentalmachu-picchu-joya-emperador-noticia-836705 |title=Mañana se estrena filme 'Machu Picchu: la joya del emperador' |trans-title=The film 'Machu Picchu, The Jewel of the Emperor' Opens Tomorrow |work=[[El Comercio (Peru)|El Comercio]] |language=Spanish |date=2 July 2011 |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://larepublica.pe/18-06-2011/mavila-huertas-regresa-al-cusco-por-documental |title=Mávila Huertas regresa al Cusco por documental |trans-title=Mávila Huertas Returns to Cusco for Documentary |work=[[La República]] |language=Spanish |date=18 June 2011 |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In 2012 she wrote and directed her second documentary, ''Amazonas, la ruta indomable'' (Amazonas, the Indomitable Route).<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://archivo.elcomercio.pe/tvmas/television/mavila-huertas-me-senti-indiana-jones-grabandoamazonas-ruta-indomable-noticia-1452087 |title=Mávila Huertas: 'Me sentí Indiana Jones grabando "Amazonas, la ruta indomable"' |trans-title=Mávila Huertas: 'I felt like Indiana Jones filming "Amazonas, la ruta indomable"' |last=del Águila |first=Sonia |work=[[El Comercio (Peru)|El Comercio]] |language=Spanish |date=6 August 2012 |access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In mid-2013 Huertas shot ''Frontera azul, mar peruano'' (Blue Border, Peruvian Sea), completing the documentary trilogy.
==Television work== ===Presenter=== * ''Primero a las 8'' ([[Canal N]], 2013 – present) * ''{{ill|Pequeños gigantes (Peru)|es|Pequeños gigantes (Perú)|lt=Pequeños gigantes}}'' ([[América Televisión]], 2013), guest judge * ''{{ill|América Noticias (Peru)|es|América noticias (Perú)|lt=América Noticias - Edición Central}}'' (América Televisión, 2004 – present) * ''{{ill|ATV Noticias|es}}'' ([[Andina de Televisión]], 2003–2004) * ''Reportajes ''([[Panamericana Televisión]], 2002–2003) * ''{{ill|Buenos Días, Perú|es}}'' ([[Panamericana Televisión]], 2001–2003) * ''América Noticias - Primera Edición'' (América Televisión, 1999–2001)
===Reporter=== * ''La Clave'' * ''Contrapunto''
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Nadine Labaki | native_name = نادين لبكي | image = Nadine Labaki by Matteo Chinellato (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Labaki in 2012 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|2|18}} | birth_place = [[Baabdat]], [[Lebanon]]<ref>[http://www.annahar.com/article/120933-%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%86-%D9%84%D8%A8%D9%83%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%AE%D8%B1%D8%AC%D8%A9-%D9%84%D8%A8%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%88%D9%85%D9%85%D8%AB%D9%84%D8%A9-%D8%A3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%A9 نادين لبكي مخرجة لبنانية وممثلة أوروبية]</ref> | occupation = Actress, director | years_active = 1997–present | spouse = [[Khaled Mouzanar]] | children = 2 | website = {{URL|http://www.nadinelabaki.com}} }}
'''Nadine Labaki''' ({{lang-ar|نادين لبكي}}; born February 18, 1974) is a [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] actress and director.
==Biography==
===Early life=== Nadine Labaki spent the first seventeen years of her life, living in a war torn environment, by 1991 the [[Lebanese Civil War|civil war]] in Lebanon had ended.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?hl=en&lr=&id=uuueBgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=%22Nadine+Labaki%22+%22neorealism%22+%22politics%22&ots=yxRJRN6J95&sig=tsfhhl81Nbrn6sTnJfN0yjd6Zc8#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=New Voices in Arab Cinema|last=Armes|first=Roy|date=2015-01-29|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=2015|isbn=9780253015280|location=|pages=232|language=en}}</ref> She began her career with [[Studio El Fan]], a Lebanese talent show, in 1990. The show aired during the 1970s, which continued through to the early 2000s. At the talent show, Labaki won a prize for directing various music video productions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?hl=en&lr=&id=KANOAYzkhA8C&oi=fnd&pg=PA97&dq=Nadine+Labaki&ots=mPP71-VVwn&sig=ebzPh5HVrV86xw8dOJkqGpvGWV0#v=onepage&q=Nadine%20Labaki&f=false|title=Music and Media in the Arab World|last=Frishkopf|first=Michael Aaron|date=2010|publisher=American Univ in Cairo Press|year=|isbn=9789774162930|location=|pages=103 and 104|language=en}}</ref>
Labaki obtained a degree in audiovisual studies at [[Saint Joseph University]] in [[Beirut]]. In 1997, she directed her graduation film, ''11 Rue Pasteur'', which won the Best Short Film Award at the Biennale of Arab Cinema at the [[Arab World Institute]] in [[Paris]]. Labaki is unique among her fellow Lebanese and Arab Film Makers in that she was not educated or trained abroad.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?hl=en&lr=&id=uuueBgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=%22Nadine+Labaki%22+%22neorealism%22+%22politics%22&ots=yxRJRN6J95&sig=tsfhhl81Nbrn6sTnJfN0yjd6Zc8#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=New Voices in Arab Cinema|last=Armes|first=Roy|date=2015-01-29|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=2015|isbn=9780253015280|location=|pages=232|language=en}}</ref>
In 1998, she attended a workshop in acting at the [[Cours Florent]] in Paris. She went on to direct advertisements and music videos for renowned Middle Eastern singers, for which she won several awards.
===As a director=== [[File:Nadine Labaki.jpg|thumb|upright|Labaki in 2007]] In 2003, Labaki's name began to become more popular within the Arab media. 2003 was also the year when she began directing music videos for singer [[Nancy Ajram]]. The song, "Akhasmak ah" (I'll taunt you), sparked controversy due to the nudity presented and its sexually explicit dancing.<ref name=":03">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?hl=en&lr=&id=KANOAYzkhA8C&oi=fnd&pg=PA97&dq=Nadine+Labaki&ots=mPP71-VVwn&sig=ebzPh5HVrV86xw8dOJkqGpvGWV0#v=onepage&q=Nadine%20Labaki&f=false|title=Music and Media in the Arab World|last=Frishkopf|first=Michael Aaron|date=2010|publisher=American Univ in Cairo Press|year=|isbn=9789774162930|location=|pages=103 and 104|language=en}}</ref>
In 2005, Labaki took part in the [[Cannes Film Festival]] Residence for six months, during that time, she wrote ''[[Caramel (film)|Caramel]]'', her first feature film. In 2006, she directed and played one of the leading roles in ''Caramel'', which showcases a Beirut that most people are not familiar with. Rather than tackle political issues that have plagued Lebanon, she presents a comedy that deals with five Lebanese women in Beirut who gather at a beauty salon and deal with issues related to love, sexuality, tradition, disappointment, and everyday ups and downs. The film premiered at the Directors' Fortnight at the Cannes Film Festival in 2007, which was a commercial success in the summer of that same year. It sold worldwide and collected important prizes at many festivals around the world, garnering Labaki much acclaim both as a director and actress. It also put her on Variety's 10 Directors to Watch list at the [[Sundance Film Festival]]. In 2008 the [[Minister of Culture (France)|French Ministry of Culture and Communication]] gave her the Insignia of Chevalier in the [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres|Order of Arts and Letters]].
In 2010, Labaki directed and starred in her second feature film, ''Where Do We Go Now?'' The film humorously tackles a delicate subject about a village in which church and mosque stand side by side as women try to keep their blowhard men from starting a religious war.
The film also premiered at the Cannes Film Festival in the "[[Un Certain Regard]]" category in 2011. The film won the Cadillac people’s choice award at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]]. It also collected many other awards in festivals around the world, like Cannes Film Festival, [[San Sebastián International Film Festival]], [[Stockholm Film Festival]]. The film was also nominated for best foreign film at the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award|Critics Choice Awards]] in Los Angeles.
In late 2013, Nadine Labaki started work on her third feature film called “Cafarnaúm” (Capernaum) which was selected to compete for the Palme d'Or at [[2018 Cannes Film Festival]] .<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/festivals/1201776734-1201776734/|title=Lebanese Director Nadine Labaki Preps ‘Cafarnaúm’ (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Keslassy|first=Elsa|date=2016-05-17|work=Variety|access-date=2018-03-01|language=en-US}}</ref> She intends to use mostly non-professional actors for this film, similar to her past works.
Labaki's style of cinematography uses cinematic conventions, such as illuminations, atmosphere lighting, and silence to help convey the meaning in her films. Despite the often dangerous political situations Labaki continues to write and direct films that do not focus on conflict.
She was selected to be on the jury for the [[Un Certain Regard]] section of the [[2015 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/article/61349.html |title=Un Certain Regard Jury 2015 |date=7 May 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015 |work=Cannes Film Festival}}</ref>
Following the success of her third feature, [[Capernaum (film)|''Capernaum'']], which won the Jury Prize at the [[2018 Cannes Film Festival]], [[Creative Artists Agency]] (CAA) signed Labaki in all areas, but she continues to be represented in France by Art Media Agency<ref>{{cite web|title="‘Capernaum’ Director Nadine Labaki Signs With CAA"|url=http://deadline.com/2018/05/capernaum-director-nadine-labaki-signs-caa-1202388485/}}</ref>.
===As an actress=== Nadine Labaki started acting in short films during the early 2000s.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?hl=en&lr=&id=FtzFBQAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PT17&dq=Nadine+Labaki+-+L.A.+Welcomes+Lebanese+Filmmaker+Nadine+Labaki,+Who+Wrote,+Stars+in+%22Caramel%22&ots=Rql4y-YfZy&sig=3cEa-Xr58IZFFBa-c0dIzdZxT0E#v=onepage&q=nadine%20labaki&f=false|title=The Global Film Book|last=Stafford|first=Roy|date=2014-01-10|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9781136474583|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref>
As an actor, Labaki starred in ''Stray Bullet,'' directed by [[Georges Hachem]] in 2010. She appears in the Moroccan production ''Rock The Casbah,'' directed by [[Laila Marrakchi]], alongside actors [[Hiam Abbas]] and [[Lubna Azabal]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2015}}
==Politics== Through her films, Nadine Labaki connects themes from the Arab world and the Western world. Her transnational feminism highlights ordinary women affected by complex realities deeply rooted in decades of political turmoil. Nadine Labaki was a candidate on the list of the new political movement [[Beirut Madinati]] for the capital’s [[Beirut municipal election, 2016|May 2016 local election]].<ref>[http://beirutmadinati.com/candidates/?lang=en Our Candidates]. [[Beirut Madinati]] website, retrieved 27 Nov 2016.</ref> Beirut Madinati focuses on social justice and the good of the public utilizing a diverse group of citizens as representatives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://beirutmadinati.com/|title=Beirut Madinati|website=beirutmadinati.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref>
Despite achieving about 40% of the popular vote, the movement lost against its opponent, the 'Beirutis' list' supported by [[Saad Hariri]], in all 6 out of 12 wards, but did not gain a single seat under the election’s one-district [[First-past-the-post voting|First-past-the-post system]]. ==Personal life== Labaki is multilingual, fluent in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[French language|French]], [[English language|English]] and [[Italian language|Italian]]. In 2007, she married musician and composer [[Khaled Mouzanar]]. In 2009, Nadine Labaki gave birth to her first boy, Walid. In 2016 Nadine gave birth to a daughter.
In 2016, Labaki received an honorary degree from the American University of Beirut and was the speaker at the 150th Commencement Ceremony.
==Filmography==
===As a director=== *''[[Caramel (film)|Caramel]]'' or ''Sukkar Banat''. Premiered at the 2007 [[Cannes Film Festival]]. (See [[Caramel]] for a list of awards and nominations). *''[[Where Do We Go Now?]]'' released and premiered as part of the [[Un Certain Regard]] section at the [[2011 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="Cannes">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/article/58041.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Official Selection |accessdate=2011-04-14|work=Cannes}}</ref> (See ''[[Where Do We Go Now?]]'' for a list of awards and nominations). *''[[Rio, I Love You]]'' segment: ''O Milagre'' <ref>{{cite web |url=http://thefilmstage.com/news/rio-i-love-you-omnibus-unveils-first-images-directors-and-cast/ |title=‘Rio, I Love You’ Omnibus Unveils Directors, Cast and First Images |publisher=The Film State |date=November 12, 2013}}</ref> *''[[Capernaum (film)|Capernaum]]'' (2018)
===As an actress=== * ''Ramad'' (Ashes) - a short film by [[Joana Hadjithomas|Joanna Hadjithomas]] and [[Khalil Joreige]] (2003) * '' The Seventh Dog'' - a short film by Zeina Durra * ''Non métrage Libanais'' (2003) - a short film by Wissam Smayra; Role as Nina * ''[[Bosta (film)|Bosta]]'' - a long feature by [[Philippe Aractingi]]; Role as Alia * ''[[Caramel (film)|Caramel]]'' or ''Sukkar Banat'' (2007) - Role as Layale * ''[[Stray Bullet (2010 film)|Stray Bullet]]'' (2010) - Role as Noha * ''Al Abb Wal Gharib'' [[The Father and the Foreigner|The Father And The Foreigner]] (2010) by Ricky Tognazzi * ''[[Where Do We Go Now?]]'' (2011) - Role as Amale * ''[[Rock the Casbah (2013 film)|Rock The Casbah]]'' (2013) * ''[[Mea Culpa (film)|Mea Culpa]]'' (2014) * ''[[Rio, I Love You]]'' (2014) - Role as self * ''[[La Rançon de la gloire]]'' (2014) * ''[[The Idol (2015 film)|The Idol]]'' (2015)
== Other work == In 2014, Labaki was the goodwill ambassador for the bi-lingual and multimedia campaign produced by The Brave Heart Fund (BHF). Based out of the Children’s Heart Center at the [[American University of Beirut]] Medical Center, the BHF creates awareness and helps to fund operations and procedures for under privileged children with Congenital Heart Disease.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.braveheartfund.org/newsDetail.php?id=426|title=News Details - Brave Heart|website=www.braveheartfund.org|access-date=2018-03-01}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{more citations needed|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Perkins Opera House | image = Monticello opera house01.jpg | caption = | location = [[Monticello, Florida|Monticello]], [[Florida]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|32|41|N|83|52|15|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built = 1890<ref name=fhtp>{{cite web|url=http://www.flheritage.com/facts/reports/places/index.cfm?fuseaction=ListAreas&county=jefferson|title=Jefferson County listings|date=2007-02-20|work=Florida's History Through Its Places|publisher=Florida's Office of Cultural and Historical Programs|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070216142118/http://www.flheritage.com/facts/reports/places/index.cfm?fuseaction=ListAreas&county=Jefferson|archivedate=2007-02-16|df=}}</ref> | architect = | architecture = [[Vernacular architecture|Masonry Vernacular]] with [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival]] elements<ref name=fhtp/> | added = September 14, 1972 | refnum = 72000330<ref name=nrhp>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/FL/Jefferson/state.html|title=National Register of Historical Places - Florida (FL), Jefferson County|date=2007-02-20|work=National Register of Historic Places|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = }}
The '''Perkins Opera House''' (also known as the '''Monticello Opera House''') is a historic [[opera house|theatre]] in [[Monticello, Florida]]. It is located at the corner of [[U.S. Route 90 in Florida|Washington Street]] and [[U.S. Route 19 in Florida|Jefferson Street]].
== History == The ''Perkins Block'' was built in 1890 by Monticello businessman John H. Perkins. This building included three first floor bays housing Perkins' mercantile interests - a [[general store]] and sewing machine shop, a [[hardware store]] and a farm implement supply store. In addition, Perkins built a stable behind the building from which horses, mules and wagons were sold. The second floor of the Perkins Block included a large foyer and an opera house boasting unparalleled [[acoustics]] and the largest [[Stage (theatre)|stage]] in the region.
Perkins had hopes of establishing the opera house as a major theater in the [[Southern United States|South]]. For several years, performances included both professional touring groups and local productions. Shortly after the turn of the century, however, the [[railroads]] were re-routed, by-passing Monticello. The wealthy patrons who had once wintered in south Georgia and north Florida sought destinations further south in Florida, and the opera house faced financial disaster.
Unable to attract the once-popular theatre productions, Perkins discontinued live performances. A failed attempt to utilize the building as a movie theater led to the abandonment of the auditorium. Although the downstairs bays saw continuous occupation for a variety of uses, the opera house stood idle and soon fell into disrepair.
In 1972, the vision of a handful of interested people saved the opera house, with its falling plaster and leaking roof, from the destruction of the wrecker's ball. An organization was formed to provide opportunities for young performers and restore the opera house.
The Monticello Opera Company was formed in March of that year and performed at the first fund-raising event at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Phipps.
[[File:Monticello opera house02.jpg|thumb|left|The Perkins opera house, seen from the east side]]
The purchase of the Perkins Block was consummated on October 17, 1973. On that date, the Monticello Opera House, Inc. purchased the building with money raised through fund-raising efforts, a grant from the State of Florida and a private donation from Mrs. Dorothy Simpson, who held one-half interest in the building.
Maintenance and restoration of the facility continues to this day. In a joint effort with the Florida Department of State, Division of Historic Resources, a restoration project was completed in the area of the original stairway leading to the auditorium balcony. The construction brought the facility into compliance with fire code regulations to allow the lawful use of seating in the balcony. The project was completed with a sensitivity to the original architectural features and makes use of original molding and wainscoting wherever possible. Although the original seating in the balcony remained intact, the seats on the main level of the theater had to be replaced. The current seating was donated by [[Tallahassee Community College]] President during the school's renovation of its theater. Installation of the "new" seats was accomplished entirely with volunteer labor from members of the community.
Although the downstairs had been remodeled to accommodate those with disabilities, it was not until May 2004, that the theater became accessible. In 1999 $25,000 was donated in the memory of Dr. Gerald M. Cathey to institute fund raising efforts for installation of an elevator. An additional $25,000 was raised over the course of the next two years through donations from benefactors and production proceeds from the Opera House Stage Company. A $50,000 matching grant from the Department of State, Division of Historical Resources resulted in the hiring of Riley Palmer Construction to complete this long desired renovation.
==Present usage==
The Monticello Opera House is commonly used for a variety of events including [[children's theater]], [[Mystery dinner|murder mystery dinners]] and large [[musicals]]. There is also a patio and gazebo in the back where weddings and receptions are held.

==External links== {{commons}} {{official website|http://www.monticellofloridaoperahouse.com/home.cfm}}

{{Redirect|Planography|the medical imaging technique|Tomography}} '''Planographic printing''' means printing from a flat surface, as opposed to a raised surface (as with [[relief print]]ing) or incised surface (as with [[intaglio (printmaking)|intaglio]] printing). [[Lithograph]]y and [[offset printing|offset lithography]] are planographic processes that rely on the property that water will not mix with oil. The image is created by applying a [[:wiktionary:tusche|tusche]] (greasy substance) to a plate or stone. (The term lithography comes from ''litho'', for ''stone'', and -''graph'' to draw.) Certain parts of the semi-absorbent surface being printed on can be made receptive to ink while others (the blank parts) reject it.
==See also== *[[Lithography]] *[[Viscosity printing]] *[[Flexography]]

[[Image:Bn matica e.png|right]] '''Project Rastko — Internet Library of Serb Culture''' ({{lang-sr|Пројекат Растко — Електронска библиотека српске културе, Projekat Rastko — Elektronska biblioteka srpske kulture}}) is a non-profit and non-governmental publishing, cultural and educational project dedicated to [[Serbs|Serb]] and Serb-related [[art]]s and [[humanities]]. It is named after [[Rastko Nemanjić]].
==Project== The project was established in 1997 as a part of a pan-regional Balkans Cultural Network Initiative {{Fact|date=November 2007}}. Its main activities are: * [[electronic publishing]] in the fields of [[Serbia]]n and Serbian-related arts and humanities * scientific and cultural conferences and studies about [[Balkan]] cultural-civilizational integration {{Fact|date=November 2007}} * bilateral and multilateral activities with other Balkan and world countries * establishing regional centres * technical training
The apex of the project is its [[digital library|electronic library]] with more than half a [[gigabyte]] of material, comprising [[e-book|electronic books]] and [[essay |articles]], [[photograph]]s and [[comic strip| comic]]s. Though most texts are in [[Serbian language]] there is a body of material in other languages, again mostly in [[English language|English]] and [[Russian language|Russian]], but also in [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Spanish language |Spanish]] and other languages.
The library contains material in both the [[public domain]] and [[copyright]]ed texts published with the authors' permissions{{Fact|date=November 2007}}, dating from earliest [[medieval]] Serb texts to contemporary [[science fiction]]. The site of the project also hosts several sites not directly related to the project.
Project Rastko also hosts the European version of [[Distributed Proofreaders]], which intends to supply [[Project Gutenberg]] with public domain texts in European languages. Project Rastko is organising a coalition of European e-libraries for the purpose of collecting public domain works, aiming to eventually have a node of Distributed Proofreaders in each European country.
==Centres== Currently (2007) the project has following regional centres:
# [[Denmark]] ([http://www.rastko.net/danmark/ Projekt Rastko — Denmark], network of electronic libraries and achievements regarding Danish culture and Danish-Serbian cultural and historical links) # [[Republic of Macedonia]] ([http://makedonija.rastko.net/default.html Project Rastko — Macedonia], electronic library of culture and tradition of Macedonia) # [[Russia]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201124915/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-ru/ Project Rastko — Russia]) # [[Podrinje|The Drina]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20120929080858/http://www.rastko.org.rs/rastko-drina/ Project Rastko — The Drina], electronic library of culture and tradition of the Drina) # [[Kashubians]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20080629091858/http://www.rastko.net/rastko-ka/ Project Rastko — Kashubia], e-library of culture and tradition of Kashubians) # [[Slovenia]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20120929081306/http://www.rastko.org.rs/rastko-sl/ Project Rastko — Slovenia], e-library of Slovenian-Serbian cultural ties) # [[Gora (region)|Gora]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20120929081010/http://www.rastko.org.rs/rastko-gora/ Project Rastko — Gora], e-library of culture and tradition of Gora and Goranies) # [[Poland]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20120929081019/http://www.rastko.org.rs/rastko-pl/ Project Rastko — Poland], library of Polish-Serbian cultural links) # [[Lusatia]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201122018/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-lu/ Project Rastko — Lusatia], electronic library of Sorbian-Serbian cultural ties) # [[Bulgaria]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201123619/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-bg/ Project Rastko — Bulgaria], library of Bulgarian-Serbian cultural links) # [[Albania]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201112307/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-al/ Project Rastko — Shkoder], library of Slavs in Albania and Albanian-Slavic cultural links) # [[Bosnian Krajina]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201112402/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-bl/ Project Rastko — Banja Luka], electronic library of culture and tradition of the Bosnian Krajina) # [[Ukraine]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201122711/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-ukr/ Project Rastko — Kiev-Lavov], electronic library of Ukrainian-Serbian cultural links) # [[Hungary]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090201125530/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-hu/ Project Rastko — Budapest-Saint Andrew], library of culture and tradition of the Serbs in Hungary) # [[Bay of Kotor]] ([http://www.rastko.org.rs/rastko-bo/ Project Rastko — Bay of Kotor], electronic library of culture and tradition of Bocca) # [[Montenegro]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090119133020/http://rastko.org.rs/rastko-cg/index_c.html Project Rastko — Cetinje], electronic library of culture and tradition of Montenegro) # [[Kosovo]] ([http://www.rastko.org.rs/kosovo/ Project Rastko — Kosovo and Metohija], electronic library of culture and tradition of the southern Serbian province) # [[Romania]] ([http://www.rastko.org.rs/rastko-ro/001a.htm Project Rastko — Romania], library of the culture of Serbs in Romania) # [[Italy]] ([http://italia.rastko.net/ Rastko Project — Italy], electronic library of Serbian-Italian cultural links)
Each of them is autonomous, and develops its projects and activities through local academic, cultural, media NGOs and individuals, including strong co-operation with ethnic [[minority group|minorities]] centres. Future activities of Belgrade centre will include projects about [[Slovaks|Slovak]], [[Jew]]ish and [[Romani people| Roma/Gypsy]] as well as for 29 other ethnocultural minorities in South-Eastern Europe.
== See also == * [[List of digital library projects]]
== References == ''This article incorporates some copyrighted text from the website of the project that is used with permission.''

'''Puppy pregnancy syndrome''' is a [[psychosomatic]] illness in humans brought on by [[mass hysteria]].
The syndrome is thought to be localized to villages in several states of [[India]], including [[West Bengal]], [[Assam]], [[Bihar]], [[Jharkhand]], [[Orissa]], and [[Chhattisgarh]], and has been reported by tens of thousands of individuals.<ref name="Welle">{{cite news | title = Medicine challenges Indian superstition | newspaper = Deutsche Welle World | date = December 31, 2012 | accessdate = March 26, 2013|first=Shaikh Azizur |last=Rahman|url=http://www.dw.de/medicine-challenges-indian-superstition/a-16489334 }}</ref> It is far more prevalent in areas with little access to education.<ref name="Welle"/>
People suffering from this condition believe that shortly after being bitten by a dog, puppies are conceived within their abdomen.<ref name="Welle"/> This is said to be especially likely if [[Canine reproduction#Copulation|the dog is sexually excited]] at the time of the attack.<ref name="Scientific">{{Cite web| last = Bering | first = Jesse | title = Puppy Pregnancy Syndrome: Men Who Think They Are Pregnant with Dogs | publisher = Scientific American | date = November 15, 2011 | url = http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/bering-in-mind/2011/11/15/puppy-pregnancy-syndrome-men-who-are-pregnant-with-dogs/ | accessdate = March 26, 2013}}</ref> Victims are said to bark like dogs, and have reported being able to see the puppies inside them when looking at water, or hear them growling in their abdomen.<ref name="Welle"/><ref name="Scientific"/><ref name="Radio">{{cite news | last = Achin | first = Kurt | title = Bizarre Medical Myth Persists In Rural India | newspaper =Voice of America | date = March 26, 2012 | accessdate = March 26, 2013|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/bizarre-medical-myth-persists-in-rural-india-143818636/179310.html}}</ref> It is believed that the victims will eventually die – especially men, who will give birth to their puppies through the penis.<ref name="Scientific"/><ref name="Radio"/>
[[Witch doctors]] offer oral cures, which they claim will dissolve the puppies, allowing them to pass through the digestive system and be excreted "without the knowledge of the patient".<ref name="Welle"/><ref name="Scientific"/>
Doctors in India have tried to educate the public about the dangers of believing in this condition.<ref name="Radio"/> Most sufferers are referred to psychiatric services, but in rare instances patients fail to take anti-[[rabies]] medication in time, thinking that they have puppy pregnancy syndrome and thus the witch doctor's medicine will cure them.<ref name="Welle"/><ref name="Scientific"/> This is further compounded by witch doctors stating that their medicine will fail if sufferers seek conventional treatment.<ref name="Welle"/>
Some psychiatrists believe that the syndrome meets the criteria for a [[Culture-bound syndrome|culture-bound disorder]].<ref name="Scientific"/>
==See also== *[[Clinical lycanthropy]] *[[List of superstitions in India]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last=Chowdhury|first=A.N..|last2=Mukherjee|first2= Himadri |last3= Ghosh|first3= Kumar Kanti|last4= Chowdhury|first4= Shyamali|title=Puppy pregnancy in humans: a culture-bound disorder in rural West Bengal, India|journal=The International Journal of Social Psychiatry|date=March 2003|volume=49|issue=1|pages=35–42|pmid=12793514|url=http://isp.sagepub.com/content/49/1/35|doi=10.1177/0020764003049001536}}
{{Superstitions}}

{{use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{use list-defined references|date=July 2013}} {{use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox university |name = Saint Martin's School of Art |image_name = St martins art school 1.jpg |caption = The Saint Martin's School of Art building, in [[Charing Cross Road]] |established = {{Start date|1854}} | closed = {{End date|1989}} |type =academy of art and design |faculty = |head_label = |head = |undergrad = |postgrad = |city = [[London]] |country = [[United Kingdom]] | coor = {{Coord|51.5142|-0.1299|display=inline,title}} |campus = 107–109 Charing Cross Road |affiliations = |website = }}
'''Saint Martin's School of Art''' was an [[art school|art college]] in London, England. It offered foundation and degree level courses. It was established in 1854, initially under the aegis of the church of [[St Martin-in-the-Fields]]. Saint Martin's became part of the [[London Institute]] in 1986,<ref name=hist/> and in 1989 merged with the [[Central School of Art and Design]] to form [[Central Saint Martins College of Arts and Design]].<ref name=frieze/>
==History== Saint Martin's School of Art was established in 1854 by [[Henry Mackenzie (bishop)|Henry Mackenzie]], [[vicar]] of the church of St Martin-in-the-Fields. It became independent from the church in 1859.<ref name=oxford/>
The school was at first housed on the top floor of [[St Martin's Northern School]] in Shelton Street (then called Castle Street), to the north of [[Long Acre, London|Long Acre]].<ref name=aim25/>
The Gilbert-Garret Competition for Sketching Clubs was founded at Saint Martin's in 1870, when John Parker was headmaster. It was named after [[John Gilbert (painter)|Sir John Gilbert]], the first president of the school.<ref name=gilbert>[s.n.] (1904-1905). [http://chestofbooks.com/crafts/general/Arts-And-Crafts-Magazine/Art-School-Exhibitions-2.html#.UfzxAOBEBID Art School Exhibitions]. ''Arts and Crafts: a monthly practical magazine for the studio, the workshop & the home''. '''1–2'''. UIN: BLL01002839292. (unpaginated online text). Accessed August 2013.</ref>
From 1952 to 1979 [[Frank Martin (sculptor)|Frank Martin]] was head of the [[sculpture]] department of Saint Martin's. He brought in young sculptors such as [[Anthony Caro]], [[Robert Clatworthy (sculptor)|Robert Clatworthy]], [[Elizabeth Frink]] and [[Eduardo Paolozzi]] to teach, and also employed as part-time teachers recent graduates of the department, including David Annesley, Michael Bolus, [[Phillip King (artist)|Phillip King]], [[Tim Scott (artist)|Tim Scott]], Bill Tucker and [[Isaac Witkin]].<ref name=frieze/><ref name=poussin/><ref name=mclean/> Caro's influence was particularly strong, and the group around him came to be known as the New Generation of British sculptors. The sculpture department became, in the words of Tim Scott: "the most famous in the art world".<ref name=mclean/>
The first public performance of the [[Sex Pistols]] took place at the school on 6 November 1975; they were the support band for a group called [[Bazooka Joe (band)|Bazooka Joe]].<ref name=sharp/>
==Alumni== {{See also|List of alumni of Saint Martin's School of Art|Category:Alumni of Saint Martin's School of Art}} Notable alumni of Saint Martin's School of Art include: * [[Sade Adu]]<ref name=bbc/> * [[Pierce Brosnan]]<ref name=jones/> * [[Peter Doig]]<ref name=adams/> * [[John Galliano]]<ref name=tamsin/> * [[Bill Gibb]]<ref name=tamsin/> * [[Gilbert and George]]<ref name=tamsin/><ref name=frieze/> * [[Anthony Gormley]]<ref name=tamsin/> * [[Katharine Hamnett]]<ref name=tamsin/> * [[Richard Long (artist)|Richard Long]]<ref name=frieze/> * [[Bruce Oldfield]]<ref name=tamsin/>

Accessed August 2013.</ref>

But is it art?: King's Cross premises a far cry from Soho 'hell', but some students fear college will have lost its charm]. ''The Guardian''. Accessed August 2013.</ref>

revision.text:
{{About|the art form|the record label|spinART Records}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2007}}
[[Image:spinartjg.jpg|thumb|right|''Spin art'']] '''Spin art''' is an art form that uses [[paint]], a canvas such as glossy cardboard and a spinning platform. It is primarily used to entertain and expose [[children]] to the process of art creation, although it can be enjoyed by people of all ages.
==Techniques== [[Image:SPINARTTIMELAPSE.gif|thumb|left|''Spin art time lapse'']] To create spin art, an artist initially decorates or drips paint onto a canvas. The canvas can be anything; however, the most common form of canvas is a small rectangular piece of cardboard. Before the paint on the canvas dries, the artist secures the canvas to a platform that can be rotated at high speed. Once the canvas is secure, the artist can then begin spinning the canvas. Most spinning platforms are electrical or battery operated, with more elaborate platforms enabling the artist to vary the rotational speed.
As the canvas rotates, [[centrifugal force]]s draw the wet paint outwards, creating intricate designs. The artist can drip more paint onto the canvas while it is spinning, thus layering paints on top of each other, creating different effects. Using different colors, a skilled spin artist can blend colors together into subtle designs. At any point during this process, the artist can stop the spinning platform to view the canvas. Since the canvas is usually rotating at a high rate, it is difficult if not impossible to view the image on the canvas until the platform has stopped spinning, thus creating a sense of surprise and uncertainty during the creation process.
<gallery> File:Artopia 2009 - spin art 01.jpg|Making spin art on old phonograph records. Paint is applied… File:Artopia 2009 - spin art 02.jpg|…and the disc is spun at a rapid rate… File:Artopia 2009 - spin art 03.jpg|…resulting in a spin art piece. </gallery>
==Fine art== <!-- done, perhaps {{Cleanup section|reason=full of artists with no valid references|date=January 2014}} --> [[Image:Spin painting annick gendron.jpg|thumb|right| ''Spin painting",oil on [[plexiglas]] by Annick Gendron (1969)]]
Since the 1960s spin art can be seen in the works of certain contemporary artists. The artists using this technique often reconfigure their own machines by incorporating a more powerful engine than those belonging to schools. The variety of results that this technique produces gives us a good idea of the infinite possibilities. [[Image:Hirst-Beautiful.jpg|thumb|right| ''Beautiful revolving sphincter, oops brown painting'' by Damien Hirst (2003)]]
Professional artists:
'''Alfons Schilling''' {{main article|Alfons Schilling}} During the 1960s Alfons Schilling was one of the first artists to become interested in spin art. action painting also had a large influence on his work and added to its originality. Instead of installing it vertically he did it horizontally.
'''Annick Gendron''' {{main article|Annick Gendron}} From 1968 to 1973 the French artist Annick Gendron used industrial wheels to spin paint on Plexiglas. At the end of the 1960s she was one of the first artist to use centrifugal force to produce large-sized artworks. Inspired by children's games : spin art, spin painting, her goal was to transcend this modest use to get the most spectacular effects from it. Damien Hirst got the same idea in the 1990s, as her he transcends the original practice, by the use of more spectacular materials, sizes, shapes, and skill improvement. Her work has been shown at the Raymond Duncan Gallery, at the [[Bernheim-Jeune]] Gallery, at the Salon des Indépendants and Surindependant at the Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, at the Salon des Artistes Français at the Grand Palais and the Salon d'Automne in Paris.
'''Damien Hirst''' {{main article|Damien Hirst}} From 1995 the British artist Damien Hirst started a series of spin paintings. His finished pieces are circular in shape and mounted onto steel frames. This is a series of original works of art and screen prints. He was inspired by memories of the technique of spin painting which he saw as a child on the BBC's ''Blue Peter''.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/hirsts-spinning-wheel-brings-good-fortune-1155421.html Hirst's spinning wheel brings good fortune]</ref>
'''Lawrence Stafford'''
During the late 1960s developed a spinning rotating machine on which he attached raw canvas and sprayed acrylic paint while the drum spun. He exhibited those abstract paintings in the United States and in Germany in 1968-1969. Several are in important museum collections including the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]].<ref>[http://www.abstract-art.com/abstraction/l1_7pntgrs_Show_fldr/47Stafford.html Abstract-Art.com, Lawrence Stafford]</ref>
'''Mark Chadwick'''
Mark Chadwick's art is concerned by the use of machines in a production of an artwork, questioning what happens to an artwork once a machine has been used in its production. Chadwick often creates paintings using the spinning technique to introduce the element of chance and questioning the control of the artist. He consistently changes the method and considers all types of aspects to create different works.<ref>http://www.riseart.com/article/2013-05-01-introducing-mark-chadwick</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.alfons-schilling.com/ Alfons Schilling official] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090129111117/http://asso-action-art.fr/actionart/annick%20gendron.html Annick Gendron biography] * [http://www.whitecube.com/artists/hirst// White cube : Damien Hirst]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spin Art}} [[Category:Art genres]]

{{short description|Theater company}}
{{Infobox venue | name = Stairwell Theater | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = | location = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | coordinates = | type = Theater Company | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = {{URL|stairwelltheater.com}} | publictransit = }}
'''Stairwell Theater''' is an [[experimental theatre]] company founded in 2014 and based in [[New York City]].
==Founding and history== Founded in 2014 by [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art|L.A.M.D.A]] graduates, Sam Gibbs and Ellyn Heald, the company staged its first production, ''[[As You Like It]]'', at the [[Prospect Park (Brooklyn)|Prospect Park]] Pagoda and Standard Toykraft, Williamsburg, in May, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bike Rides in Bike Month, and Shakespeare vs. ‘Mad Men’ |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/15/nyregion/bike-rides-in-bike-month-and-shakespeare-vs-mad-men.html |publisher=New York Times |language=en}}</ref> The shows at the Prospect Park Pagoda were free of charge,<ref>{{cite web |title=As You Like It! Theater in New York |url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/theater/as-you-like-it-12 |website=Time Out New York |language=en}}</ref> following in the tradition of Gibbs' previous theater company, Free Theatre.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dinkelspiel |first1=Frances |title='Guerrilla' Shakespeare in John Hinkel Park |url=https://www.berkeleyside.com/2010/07/23/guerrilla-shakespeare-in-john-hinkel-park |website=Berkeleyside |date=23 July 2010}}</ref>
In 2015, the company was granted [[Fractured Atlas]], non-profit, fiscal sponsorship.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stairwell Theater |url=https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=13028#about_project |website=www.fracturedatlas.org |language=en}}</ref>
In December 2015, Stairwell Theater staged ''Ubu Rex'', an immersive cabaret production based on the 19th-century play [[Ubu Roi]], at the DIY punk rock venue Aviv, [[Greenpoint, Brooklyn|Greenpoint]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Stairwell Theater |url=http://bedfordandbowery.com/2015/12/start-a-dirty-food-fight-at-this-immersive-macbeth-parody/ |website=Bedford + Bowery}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=DIY Venue Aviv in Greenpoint Closing at End of October, Owners Say |url=https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20160831/greenpoint/diy-venue-aviv-greenpoint-closing-at-end-of-october-owners-say/ |website=DNAinfo New York}}</ref>
In 2016, the company participated in SONNET REMIX 2, a celebration of [[Shakespeare]]'s Sonnets, at [[West Park Presbyterian Church]].<ref>{{cite web |title= West Park Presbyterian Church |url=http://www.westparkpresbyterian.org/category/past-events/ |website=west park presbyterian}}</ref>
In 2018, Stairwell Theater staged a workshop version of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' at [[Old First Reformed Church]], set in a tribalized contemporary society where team sports basketball dominates society.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Desk |first1=BWW News |title=Stairwell Theater Presents ROMEO AND JULIET |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/brooklyn/article/Stairwell-Theater-Presents-ROMEO-AND-JULIET-20180804 |website=BroadwayWorld.com |language=en}}</ref>
==Production history== *''[[As You Like It]]'' (2015) *''[[Ubu Roi|Ubu Rex]]'' (2015) *''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (2018)
==External links== * [http://www.stairwelltheater.com/ Stairwell Theater website]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Theatre companies in New York City]] [[Category:Performing groups established in 2014]] [[Category:Performance art in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2014]] [[Category:Off-Off-Broadway]] [[Category:Shakespearean theatre companies]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Henri Motte - La fiancée de Bélus (1885).jpg | image_size = 250px | title = The Fiancee of Belus | artist = [[Henri-Paul Motte]] | year = 1885 | medium = [[Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 178 | width_metric = 122 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Paris]] | museum = [[Musée d'Orsay]] }} '''''The Fiancée of Belus''''' ({{lang-fr|La fiancée de Bélus}}) is a painting by French artist [[Henri-Paul Motte]] based on a fanciful [[Babylonia]]n ritual associated with deity [[Bel (mythology)|Belus]] (Bel). According to that ritual, Bel was offered a girl who sat on the lap of the Bel's statue overnight, and then was replaced by another, all of whom were the winners of daily beauty contests.<ref name="interview">{{cite web | url =http://fr.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/943594/interview-de-come-fabre-deux-toiles-insolites-entrent-au-musee |title=Interview de Côme Fabre : deux toiles insolites entrent au Musée d'Orsay|language=French|publisher=[[Louise Blouin Media]]| date=8 August 2013| accessdate =4 January 2016}}</ref> Motte cited as a reference the Greek historian [[Herodotus]], but the related quote was later found to be invented.<ref name="interview"/> ''The Fiancee of Belus'' features oversized, [[Academic art|Academic style]], while the foreground shows blood spattered by the brush.<ref name="blou">{{cite web | url =http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/944399/musee-dorsay-curator-tackles-the-ultimate-taboo-academic-art|title=Musee D'Orsay Curator Tackles the Ultimate Taboo: Academic Art|publisher=[[Louise Blouin Media]]| date=15 Aug 2013| accessdate =17 Dec 2015}}</ref> To restore the interior of the Babylonian temple, Motte copied the Greek temple in Olympia, while the sculpture is inspired by [[lamassu]].<ref name="interview"/>
In 2013, the painting was acquired by the [[Musée d'Orsay]] where it is presently kept. It was previously housed in [[Galerie Vincent Lecuyer]], near Musée d’Orsay and was exhibited in Brussels at [[BRAFA Art Fair]] and [[PAD fair]] in Paris.<ref name="blou"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/collections/catalogue-des-oeuvres/notice.html?no_cache=1&nnumid=165048&cHash=81cda3b439 Musée d'Orsay entry]
